# Discord Chat Analysis for ðŸ’»â”‚developers

## 1. Summary:
The discussion centers around lightmap baking in 3D models, specifically using geometry nodes. Ashxn initially notes that geometry nodes aren't supported by GLTF, but the functionality could be implemented with regular scripting. MetaRick shares examples of a scene using a single lightmap across multiple objects, demonstrating how this approach allows for quality control by generating one or multiple maps as needed. The examples show the difference between baked and non-baked versions, with the baked version appearing visually superior. There's a brief mention of using the Needle tool, with MetaRick clarifying they're using the Unity version rather than the Blender plugin. The conversation highlights how lightmap baking can significantly enhance visual quality in 3D scenes while maintaining efficiency by using shared texture files across multiple objects.

## 2. FAQ:
Q: Can you export geometry nodes to GLTF? (implied from Ashxn's comment) A: Yes, but there are limits (answered by á²¼~/^b0gie-(.*)$/)
Q: Are you using needle-tool-blender? (asked by á²¼~/^b0gie-(.*)$/) A: No, I'm using the Unity version (answered by MetaRick)
Q: What's the advantage of this lightmap approach? (implied from MetaRick's explanation) A: You can set up a scene with multiple models using different textures, then bake them to use the same lightmap texture file (answered by MetaRick)

## 3. Help Interactions:
Helper: Ashxn | Helpee: MetaRick | Context: Discussing feasibility of implementing geometry nodes functionality | Resolution: Confirmed it's possible with regular scripting
Helper: á²¼~/^b0gie-(.*)$/ | Helpee: MetaRick | Context: Clarifying GLTF export capabilities for geometry nodes | Resolution: Confirmed export is possible with limitations
Helper: MetaRick | Helpee: Channel members | Context: Sharing examples of lightmap baking implementation | Resolution: Provided visual examples showing the difference between baked and non-baked versions

## 4. Action Items:
Technical: Implement regular scripting alternative for geometry nodes in GLTF | Description: Create scripting solution for functionality not natively supported in GLTF | Mentioned By: Ashxn
Feature: Consider implementing VRC world creator compatibility | Description: Expand the lightmap baking tool to appeal to VRChat world creators | Mentioned By: MetaRick
Technical: Investigate Blender version compatibility issues with Needle tool | Description: Address lagging in Blender 4.4.3 vs recommended 4.2 | Mentioned By: á²¼~/^b0gie-(.*)$/

# Analysis of Discord Chat in ðŸª™â”‚hyper Channel

## 1. Summary
The chat segment contains two messages discussing Hyperfy token ($HYPER) distribution and a proposed tokenomics model. The first message from Ashxn outlines the current token allocation: approximately 10% consists of unclaimed airdrops (effectively burned), 15% is linearly vested over 3 years, and 30% is allocated to a currently inactive DAO. MUDBONE then proposes a new tokenomics model to better align team and user interests. The proposal suggests implementing buybacks where the team would use a portion of fee revenue to purchase $HYPER and deposit it into a one-sided liquidity pool. Community members would stake SOL on the other side, creating a community-backed LP. This would increase liquidity, attract larger buyers, and demonstrate the team's commitment to reinvesting in $HYPER. The model includes modest APY rewards for stakers from DAO reserves, buyback programs, and unclaimed airdrop tokens. The team would still earn marketplace fees and benefit from $HYPER appreciation. This approach aims to create a positive feedback loop of usage, fees, buybacks, liquidity depth, confidence, and increased usage.

## 2. FAQ
Q: What percentage of tokens are unclaimed airdrops? (asked by Ashxn) A: Around 10%, essentially burnt. (answered by Ashxn)
Q: How much of the token supply is vested? (asked by Ashxn) A: 15% is linear vested over 3 years. (answered by Ashxn)
Q: What percentage is allocated to the DAO? (asked by Ashxn) A: 30% is allocated to the DAO, which is currently inactive. (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Where do swap fees currently go? (asked by MUDBONE) A: Right now, all fees from swap go to the team. (answered by MUDBONE)

## 3. Help Interactions
Helper: MUDBONE | Helpee: Community | Context: Lack of alignment between token and users | Resolution: Proposed a tokenomics model with buybacks and community-backed LP to create better alignment and incentives

## 4. Action Items
Feature: Implement buyback mechanism using portion of earned fees to purchase $HYPER | Description: Team would swap SOL for $HYPER and deposit into one-sided liquidity pool | Mentioned By: MUDBONE
Feature: Create community-backed LP where users stake SOL | Description: Form two-sided LP with team-provided $HYPER and community-staked SOL | Mentioned By: MUDBONE
Feature: Establish staking rewards system | Description: Modest APY for stakers sourced from DAO reserves, buyback programs, and unclaimed airdrop tokens | Mentioned By: MUDBONE
Technical: Develop token usage flywheel | Description: Create system connecting usage, fees, buybacks, LP depth, confidence, and more usage | Mentioned By: MUDBONE

MetaRick shared information about a 2D to 3D generation tool by Tencent Hunyuan that can be used for both 3D printing (high poly) and game development (low poly). He specifically highlighted the low poly version at https://3d.hunyuan.tencent.com/lowpoly, noting it works best when the input image already has a low poly aesthetic. For game development assets, he recommends using this approach rather than the high poly version. MetaRick mentioned using ChatGPT to create low poly T-pose reference images that work well with the generator. He also shared an example of his reference image with the resulting generated model including wireframe visualization.
